verb.description: Lose blood from the body as a result of injury or illness.
examples: some casualties were left to bleed to death

verb.description: Draw blood from (someone), especially as a once-common method of treatment in medicine.
Allow (fluid or gas) to escape from a closed system through a valve.
examples: open the valves and bleed air from the pump chamber

verb.description: (of a dye or color) seep into an adjacent color or area.
examples: I worked loosely with the oils, allowing colors to bleed into one another
a lot of blood was lost from the placental bleed

noun.description: The escape of fluid or gas from a closed system through a valve.
examples: the amount of air bleed from the compressor

noun.description: An instance of printing an illustration, design, or text to the edge of the page.
examples: it allows printing of a tabloid page with full bleed

phrases: this car has been bleeding me dry
the industry had been bled dry by piracy
Apparently she is nicknamed the vampire for eating up millionaires, bleeding them dry and spitting them out again.
Then he says Joseph had stated he intended to bleed Mr McKenna dry, before noting that during the case some of Joseph's editorial board resigned.
Water bosses are not the only ones bleeding us dry.
origin: Old English blÄ“dan, of Germanic origin; related to blood.
